The passage also mentions that Chelsea was leading the league at the time, and Mourinho had recently been fined £25,000 for claiming there was a "campaign" against Chelsea.

The passage describes Bob Barker's brief return to hosting "The Price is Right" on April 1 after an eight-year absence. At 91 years old, Barker, who hosted the show for 35 years before retiring in 2007, appeared on the episode and handled the first game called "Lucky Seven" before turning hosting duties back to regular host Drew Carey. The passage notes that despite his long absence, Barker performed smoothly during his return appearance.

# Concise Summary of the Passage

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested at 12:30 AM on Friday in Washington D.C. for allegedly attempting to break into a house at midnight. Baldwin faces felony charges of attempted burglary and property destruction. Following his arrest on a residential street in southeastern D.C., the Secret Service revoked his security clearance and placed him on administrative leave. Baldwin works with the foreign missions branch of the Secret Service. This incident follows another recent case where a high-ranking supervisor was put on leave for misconduct. These events add to the agency's troubles, which already include an ongoing investigation into two high-ranking officials who allegedly drove into a secure White House area after drinking.

# Summary of the Passage

A freelance photographer, Atif Saeed (38) from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to capture close-up images of a male lion at the city's Safari Park. Saeed left the safety of his car, approached within 10 feet of the lion, and lay on the ground to take photographs. The clicking sound of the camera's shutter alerted the lion, which aggressively jumped toward him, forcing Saeed to quickly retreat to his vehicle. Though Saeed laughed about the incident at the time, he later reflected that he wouldn't attempt such a dangerous photography approach again, acknowledging it was "a pretty close encounter."

# Summary of the Passage

New York City police are seeking to identify a deceased woman found unconscious on March 22 in Brooklyn's Gravesend neighborhood. The woman, estimated to be between 25-45 years old, was pronounced dead at the scene after paramedics couldn't revive her. With no identification on her body, police released images of a distinctive tattoo on her right leg featuring the name "Monique" within a heart topped with a rose. Authorities are still awaiting the medical examiner's report on the cause of death and have requested that anyone with information contact NYPD Crime Stoppers.

# Summary of the Passage

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a home on a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK in 2009 when they couldn't afford traditional property. The 18-month construction project resulted in a solar-powered, two-bedroom dwelling made of wood and steel that cost approximately $25,000. Their home in Nelson, New Zealand allows them to live almost self-sufficiently, with solar panels providing most of their electricity (their first power bill was just $25), gas powering the stove and hot water, and water sourced from a nearby spring. The interior features aromatic cypress wood, while the exterior is surrounded by trees and a brook. The couple loves their unique home and plans to build another similar one in the future.

# Summary of the Passage

Research by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University found that kindergarten children who shared iPads in classrooms performed significantly better on early literacy tests compared to both children who had individual iPads and those who had no iPads at all. The shared iPad students scored approximately 30 points higher than the other groups. The study involved 352 students in a Midwestern suburban school district over an academic year. Blackwell concluded that the collaborative learning experience around the technology, rather than just collaboration itself, made the difference. She suggested that schools should reconsider how tablets are used in early grades to maximize their effectiveness. This research contrasts with the skepticism expressed by the general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers about using technology as a teaching aid in non-IT classes.

# Summary of the Passage

A piglet born without back legs in Qionglai City, Sichuan Province, China has become an internet sensation after learning to balance and walk on just its front trotters. The heartwarming video shows the young animal taking unsteady steps while foraging for food, remarkably maintaining its balance despite nearly tipping over several times. The piglet, belonging to farmer Ms. Duan, has attracted many villagers who come to see the unusual animal. The piglet interacts normally with its siblings, all of whom were born with four legs. This isn't the first two-legged animal to gain fame in China - a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo previously became a star attraction for walking on its front paws.

The passage describes an incident during the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana where Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured when struck by Francesco Dracone's car. The accident occurred when Dracone spun while exiting his pit box on lap 25 after stopping for tires and fuel. Phillips was taken to the infield care center where he received stitches for a leg cut and was subsequently released. The race conditions were challenging due to rain that had fallen for hours before the start. Dracone did not finish the race, placing 23rd.

# Summary of the Passage

The passage describes a horrific murder captured on CCTV footage in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, killed his dancer wife Cicera Alves de Sena (stage name Amanda Bueno), 29, by repeatedly smashing her head into concrete paving 11 times and then shooting her in the face five times. The incident occurred just four days after their marriage. Severiano later confessed to police that he committed the murder out of jealousy over men looking at his wife, whom he had accused of being "a slut" during an argument overheard by a neighbor. After the murder, Severiano attempted to flee in a stolen car but was apprehended by police after crashing. Police found multiple weapons in his possession. He now faces life imprisonment.

# Summary of Sarah Wilson's Mental Health Struggle

Sarah Wilson, the 41-year-old journalist and author of "I Quit Sugar," revealed her personal battle with mental illness in an interview with Women's Weekly Australia. She disclosed that her anxiety led her to a point where she "couldn't see the existential point of continuing" and contemplated suicide.

Wilson attributed her mental health crisis to multiple factors including stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and feeling isolated from family. She described feeling alone without a husband or children, stating she "couldn't see a light at the end of the tunnel."

While Wilson struggled significantly in her younger years, she has recently "found some peace" with her condition. She believes depression and anxiety are intrinsically linked and that acknowledging this connection is crucial for addressing the increasing rates of Australian women affected by these conditions. Wilson noted that anxiety is becoming the "new depression," with Beyond Blue reporting that one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime.

# Summary of the Passage

Elena Curtin, a seven-months pregnant woman from Portland, Oregon, was charged with second-degree assault after striking her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar in November 2014. The incident occurred when Curtin returned home to find the ex-girlfriend using heroin in her bathroom and refusing to leave. Prosecutors ultimately dropped the charges, determining Curtin was "completely justified in her outrage." Oregon law permits physical force against intruders who refuse to leave a residence. According to Curtin's attorney, the ex-girlfriend had been harassing Curtin for two years and attempted to draw the boyfriend back into addiction. Curtin has since moved in with her parents, while her boyfriend, who has a history of heroin use, has reconciled with his ex-girlfriend and is not involved in his new child's life.

The passage describes a video of Gemma, a pit bull from California, who was tricked by her owner into eating a piece of broccoli among her treats. Upon tasting the vegetable, Gemma showed disgust and spat it out on the floor. The passage humorously notes that hopefully the two children she lives with won't follow her example of rejecting vegetables. When not eating, Gemma reportedly enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family.

# Summary of the Passage

HSBC apologized after a link on its official website directed visitors to a pornographic page. The issue occurred when the bank's Young Entrepreneur Awards program was discontinued in 2011, and the registration for its web address (on hsbc.com.hk) was allowed to expire. Subsequently, a pornographic website took over this address. When visitors clicked on the link from HSBC's main website, they were redirected to explicit content featuring naked women. After discovering the mistake, HSBC removed the hyperlink from its community projects webpage. The bank issued a public statement on April 20 clarifying that it had no association with the external site and apologized for any inconvenience caused. HSBC assured customers that its website and internet banking services remained secure.

# Summary of the Passage

A 13-year-old Maryland boy named Marcus called 911 when a fire broke out on the first floor of his Clinton home on Sunday morning. He and his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah were trapped in a second-floor bedroom, unable to escape through the hallway due to the heat. During the 11-minute call, Marcus remained calm, provided firefighters with clear directions to their location, and comforted his sister. Prince George's County firefighters rescued the siblings by entering through the home and breaking a window. The children were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life threatening injuries, while three other family members (Marcus's older brother, mother, and step-father) escaped on their own and were taken to MedStar Hospital.

# Summary of Blue Fluorescent Algae on Australia's East Coast

Photographer Andy Hutchinson captured remarkable images of blue fluorescent algae illuminating Jervis Bay on the south coast of New South Wales, describing it as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of light-emitting plankton. A similar display occurred at Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014. According to oceanography expert Iain Suthers from the University of New South Wales, this phenomenon is caused by Noctiluca scintillans, a single-celled phytoplankton that naturally blooms in spring and autumn. This carnivorous cell preys on diatoms (another type of algae) and produces the luminous glow as a defense mechanism.

# Summary of Breast Cancer Testing and Chemotherapy

New genetic marker tests for breast cancer patients can determine tumor aggressiveness and help identify women who may safely avoid chemotherapy after surgery. These tests screen cancer cells and quickly assess the risk of disease recurrence. For some women, the tests can confirm a recurrence risk as low as 5%, which is comparable to or better than outcomes with chemotherapy.

Currently, most breast cancer patients routinely undergo chemotherapy after tumor removal despite its difficult side effects including hair loss, nausea, fatigue, and weight changes. The newest test, called EndoPredict, allows patients with low scores to opt out of chemotherapy.

While these tests cost about £2,500 and are mostly available privately, medical professionals hope they will soon be offered through the NHS, arguing the cost would be offset by savings from reduced chemotherapy treatments. This approach represents a shift from giving chemotherapy to almost everyone toward helping patients make more informed treatment choices based on their individual risk profiles.

# Summary of Passage

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, with HMS Ocean having five pregnant sailors removed in emergency "medevacs" over nine years. At least 18 other ships also had emergency evacuations. The Ministry of Defence confirmed a strict "no touching" rule at sea, suggesting the women conceived before boarding or during leave. The data emerged nine months after Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, was flown back to the UK following allegations of a sexual relationship with a crew member. Women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990, with females making up about 9% of personnel as of 2014. Similarly, 99 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan between 2006-2013 due to pregnancy, with an additional 102 evacuated from Iraq, as military rules ban pregnant women from serving in war zones.

# Summary of the Passage

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium was discovered on the rooftop of the Japanese Prime Minister's residence in Tokyo. The drone was equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing the radioactive material, though the amount was not immediately harmful to humans. This incident occurred on the same day a Japanese court approved restarting two nuclear reactors at the Sendai plant, a controversial decision following the 2011 Fukushima disaster. Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga expressed concerns about potential drone-based terrorism, particularly for future events like the Olympics and G7 summit. While Japan restricts drone flights near airports, there are no flight restrictions over most of Tokyo, including government buildings. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe was in Indonesia at the time of the incident.

# Summary of the Passage

The passage describes a devoted Chinese security guard, Lu Xincai, who takes his 84-year-old mother with him to work every day on his motorbike. His mother suffers from Alzheimer's disease, and he fears she might get lost if left alone at home, as she had previously wandered off when collecting firewood. After his father's death earlier this year, Lu decided to take responsibility for his mother's care since his wife works in another city and his son is still in school. Each morning, he secures his mother on his motorbike with a sash around their waists and rides slowly for an hour to cover the four-kilometer journey to his workplace, a bank, where his employers have provided a room for his mother. Lu checks on her regularly during work hours and feels it's his duty to care for her as she once cared for him, saying, "I was an apple in my mum's eye, and now she's my apple."

# Summary of Passage on American Drinking Habits

The study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation reveals that heavy drinking among Americans increased by 17.2% between 2005 and 2012, primarily due to rising rates among women. Key findings include:

- In 2012, 8% of Americans were heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers
- Women's binge drinking rates increased more than seven times the rate of men over a decade
- The percentage of people who drink any alcohol has remained relatively stable
- County-level drinking rates vary widely, from 2% heavy drinkers in Hancock County, TN to 22% in Esmeralda County, NV

Experts attribute these trends to changing social norms for women, affluence in tech-centered communities, relatively cheaper alcohol prices, increased advertising, and weakened alcohol control policies. Alcohol was responsible for approximately 88,600 U.S. deaths in 2010, with excessive drinking estimated to cost over $220 billion annually.

# Summary of the Passage

UN officials warn that doctors are performing caesarean sections too frequently, putting women and babies at risk. According to the World Health Organization (WHO), caesareans should only be performed when "medically necessary" as they can lead to complications, infections, and even death. While over 25% of births in England are now by caesarean (more than double since the early 1990s), the WHO recommends this figure should ideally be between 10-15%. The WHO's position contradicts current NHS guidelines, which allow caesareans even without medical justification, including for women with tokophobia (extreme anxiety about childbirth). Caesareans are also more costly, averaging £2,369 compared to £1,665 for natural births, and research suggests up to 10% of caesareans cause infections.

# Summary of the Passage

Michelle Filkins, 44, was arrested on April 17 after allegedly breaking into a home on Martha's Vineyard owned by Mark Conklin. She reportedly lived in the $800,000 summer property for at least a week and sold or gave away the owners' belongings in what appeared to be a yard sale. When confronted by Conklin, Filkins claimed she owned the house before fleeing. She was arrested when she attempted to return to the home later that day. Filkins faces charges of breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. The Edgartown Police Department is requesting that anyone who received items from the home return them and has provided contact information for those with information about the case. Her next court appearance is scheduled for May 14.

# Summary of the Passage

A lost iPhone belonging to Bella Crooke from Melbourne was handed in to Albury Police Station on the NSW-Victoria border. Noticing the phone was unlocked, police officers posted selfies and humorous photos on Bella's Facebook page to track her down. They shared images of the phone in various locations around the station, including in a holding "cell," along with pun-filled messages about the phone being "charged" and ready for "release." Bella had lost her phone at a friend's birthday party the night before and only discovered the officers' social media activity when she arrived at the station to collect it. The officers recognized her from her Facebook photos, and Bella was amused by their creative approach. She has since secured her phone with a password and expressed gratitude to the police for their help and humor.

# Summary of the Passage

The passage describes a tragic incident in South Africa's Isimangaliso Wetland Park where a five-day-old baby hippopotamus was killed after getting caught in a fight between two adult male hippos. While the mother hippo had been protecting her calf from younger hippos, she momentarily lost sight of it, allowing a sub-adult hippo to grab the baby. Despite the mother's attempts to rescue her calf by attacking the aggressor, the sub-adult hippo bit down harder and flung the baby into the air. The incident was witnessed by Stacey Farrell, a 30-year-old tour operator, who described the mother's unsuccessful efforts to protect her young. The baby hippopotamus died from its injuries hours after the attack.

# Summary of the Passage

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, one of Britain's most expensive areas, is being sold for £575,000, which is significantly below market value because it has only three years remaining on its lease. The "unmodernised" 1,990 sq/ft maisonette features three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, utility room, lift access, parking, and a communal garden. If a buyer extends the lease, the property could be worth upwards of £6 million, though extending to a 90-year lease would likely cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million. A similar property in the same location is also available for £595,000 with the same lease limitation. Estate agent Jake Russell describes these properties as rare opportunities, while property consultant Alex Newall warns potential buyers about the massive premium required to extend the lease.

# Starbucks Computer Outage Summary

Starbucks experienced a computer outage affecting point-of-sale registers at 8,000 stores across the US and Canada. The outage, caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, prevented staff from processing credit card transactions or ringing up sales.

In response to the technical difficulties, many Starbucks locations gave away free drinks and food to customers, while some stores chose to close early. The impromptu giveaway generated significant social media activity, with customers sharing photos of their free beverages and expressing gratitude.

The outage began in the early evening on the East Coast and late afternoon on the West Coast on Friday, but was resolved by late Friday night. Starbucks announced that stores would return to "business as usual" on Saturday.

Ironically, the technical issue occurred just one day after Starbucks reported record quarterly earnings of $4.6 billion, with company shares gaining 4.4 percent to $51.50 following these impressive financial results.

# Summary of Terrorist Activities in West Wales

According to Detective Constable Gareth Jones from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit, rural areas in West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, are being used for terrorist training and Muslim radicalization. Individuals involved in these activities participate in seemingly ordinary community activities while harboring ulterior motives.

The passage notes several historical connections between Wales and extremism:
- In 1998, Abu Hamza allegedly sent 10 extremists to train in the Brecon Beacons
- Two 7/7 bombers were photographed white water rafting in North Wales in 2005
- Three Cardiff men involved in an Al-Qaeda inspired plot were arrested after meetings in a Welsh country park
- Michael Adebowale, convicted of murdering Lee Rigby, studied at the European Institute of Human Sciences near Llanybydder

DC Jones emphasized that terrorism is not limited to large cities and stressed the importance of community intelligence in countering these threats.

# Summary of the Passage

An Omura's whale was discovered washed up on a remote beach in Exmouth, Western Australia, following Tropical Cyclone Olwyn. This marks the first sighting of this species in Western Australia and only the second in Australia. Initially difficult to identify, DNA profiling confirmed it was an Omura's whale. Environment Minister Albert Jacob described the find as "highly significant" as the species was only scientifically documented in 2003, and little is known about it. Typically found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan, Omura's whales have distinctive features including 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin. The carcass has been buried, with plans to recover the skeleton later for scientific research and possible museum display.

# Summary of the Passage

The passage discusses gender bias in politics, specifically regarding Hillary Clinton's presidential candidacy. It begins by addressing comments from Cheryl Rios, a Texas businesswoman who claimed women shouldn't be presidents due to their hormones potentially causing irrational decisions like starting wars. The author counters this argument by noting that historically, male hormones have impaired leadership decisions, and studies show women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks.

The article points out that despite women outnumbering men in education and the workforce, gender bias remains a significant barrier. It cites evidence of this bias, such as the disproportionate number of men named John, Robert, William, or James on corporate boards compared to all women combined. The author argues that equality benefits everyone - improving business outcomes, family dynamics, and marriages.

The passage concludes by noting that Rios's threat to move to Canada if Clinton is elected demonstrates her ignorance, as Canada had already had a female prime minister, Kim Campbell, in 1993.

# Summary of Robert Hardy's Antique Collection Auction

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, 89, is selling his extensive collection of over 200 antiques in a £100,000 auction as he downsizes his home. The collection reflects Hardy's interests as a military historian and medieval longbow expert. Notable items include:

- A hand-painted limewood diorama of the Battle of Agincourt (estimated £4,000-£6,000)
- A yew longbow with mother-of-pearl handle
- Victorian furniture, paintings, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, and crystal chandeliers
- Rare books dating back to the 17th century

Hardy, known for roles in "All Creatures Great and Small," multiple portrayals of Winston Churchill, and as Cornelius Fudge in the Harry Potter films, expressed sadness about parting with his treasured collection. The auction will take place at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire. Despite retiring from stage acting after a fall two years ago, Hardy plans to continue television work.

# Summary of the Passage

Michael Scott Shemansky is a suspect in the murder of his 57-year-old mother, Sandra Shemansky, who was found dead in their shared home in Winter Garden after he failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son. Shemansky has a history of mental illness, including bipolar disorder, and was previously on parole for battery on law enforcement. Neighbors suggest that divorce proceedings and recent "bad news" paperwork may have triggered him, and that his mother might have prevented him from attending the court-ordered visit with his son. Authorities have recovered the murder weapon but haven't disclosed how Sandra was killed. Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication, and police are seeking information on his whereabouts.

# Summary of the Passage

Eugene, Oregon (USA) has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The IAAF Council bypassed the normal bidding process, citing a "unique strategic opportunity" to host the championships in the United States for the first time. Eugene had previously failed in its bid to host the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha, Qatar. IAAF President Lamine Diack explained that this decision was strategic, allowing them to access a key market with strong support from public authorities, the private sector, the National Olympic Committee, NBC, and the public. This departure from standard procedure is not unprecedented, as the 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan were also awarded without a bidding process.

# Summary of the Passage

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model, has been jailed for 16 years for the manslaughter of professional gambler Mehmet Hassan. Granger targeted Hassan after seeing him with cash at a London casino, using her looks to gain his trust. After a date where Hassan took her to upscale venues, she left his flat door unlocked, allowing her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson and accomplice Nicholas Chandler to enter. The men tied up Hassan and beat him to death while searching for his gambling winnings, stealing £3,000. Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and sentenced to life with a minimum of 36 years. Judge William Kennedy described the attack as "pitiless and wicked." Hassan, a divorced father of three, was known to keep large sums of cash in his home, making him vulnerable to such a scheme.

# Summary of Cesc Fabregas's Form Decline

The passage discusses Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas's apparent trend of struggling in the second half of football seasons. Despite a strong start at Chelsea following his £30 million transfer, where he accumulated 15 Premier League assists by mid-January, his form has significantly declined in 2015 with just one assist in his last five games. 

This pattern was highlighted by Barcelona when he left, noting his "downward trend" and tendency for his "magic to fade later on in each season." The 27-year-old Spanish midfielder performed poorly in Spain's 2-0 defeat to Holland, receiving a low rating from Spanish media.

While Fabregas initially appeared likely to break Thierry Henry's Premier League assist record of 20, his current form suggests he may fall short. Despite this slump, Chelsea remains on track for the Premier League title, and manager Jose Mourinho will be hoping Fabregas can regain his form for the final nine games of the season.

The passage discusses West Ham's interest in signing Jamaican football talent Deshane Beckford, a 17-year-old forward from Montego Bay United who has impressed during a two-week trial with the club's academy. Described as one of the Caribbean's hottest prospects, Beckford also has offers from Belgian clubs and has been linked with various European teams. Additionally, the passage mentions West Ham's plans for their move to the Olympic Stadium in the 2016-17 season, where they will offer the Premier League's cheapest season tickets starting at £289, as part of a strategy to fill the 54,000-capacity venue.

# Summary of the Passage

The article describes an assault on Mike Lane, a 40-year-old joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, by balaclava-wearing protesters armed with iron bars on ropes. Despite video evidence, names of suspects, and car registration numbers being provided to Wiltshire Police, they dropped the investigation after three months citing insufficient evidence. Lane was hospitalized with concussion, broken teeth, facial swelling, and has suffered memory loss since the attack. The assault occurred during a hunt using only artificial scents, not pursuing foxes. Hunt supporters are dismayed by the police's decision, with the Countryside Alliance campaigning to ban saboteurs from wearing face coverings to aid identification. Police state the case is "undetected" but could be reopened if new evidence emerges.

# Summary of the Passage

Adam Gadahn, a 36-year-old American who became al Qaeda's English-language propagandist, was killed in January in a U.S. counterterrorism operation. Born in California in 1978, Gadahn converted to Islam in 1995 and left for Pakistan in 1998, eventually rising through al Qaeda's ranks. The White House stated he was not specifically targeted in the operation. Gadahn appeared in numerous al Qaeda videos threatening attacks, criticizing U.S. presidents, and encouraging lone-wolf attacks in America. In 2006, he was indicted for treason and material support to al Qaeda, becoming one of the FBI's "most wanted terrorists." His final video appeared in September 2014. The operation that killed Gadahn was separate from another that accidentally killed American hostage Warren Weinstein and Italian hostage Giovanni Lo Porto.

# Concise Summary of the Passage

The passage describes a viral video featuring Mai Zizhuo, a five-year-old Chinese basketball prodigy who has been playing since age two and a half. The video showcases his remarkable skills, including scoring multiple hoops and simultaneously dribbling two basketballs without losing rhythm. His talents have earned him many fans across basketball-enthusiastic China, where parents are known for nurturing child prodigies. The video has generated thousands of comments from impressed viewers, with some expressing disbelief and others comparing their own skills unfavorably to the young player's abilities. The passage also mentions Yao Ming as China's biggest basketball star to date.

The passage describes that Tom O'Carroll, a leading member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll, who was previously jailed in 1981 for "corrupting public morals," attended a Hacked Off rally in Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. The rally was chaired by comedian John Cleese. Hacked Off, established after the phone-hacking scandal, is campaigning against the Independent Press Standards Organisation and wants statutory regulation of the press as recommended by the Leveson inquiry. The passage notes that O'Carroll's support is an embarrassment to Hacked Off. It also provides background on PIE, which campaigned to legalize child sex in the 1970s and 80s and had formed an alliance with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL), which lobbied to reduce the age of consent to ten.

# Summary of the Passage

The passage describes a fashion event held at Bondi's Icebergs Club in Australia, where the iconic swimming pool was drained to serve as a unique catwalk for the Ten Pieces presentation during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. Ten Pieces, a lifestyle brand headed by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss, showcased a monochrome, unisex collection of ten garments designed to be worn in 20 different ways. Models paraded through the empty concrete pool and along the break wall with the ocean as a backdrop. Guests enjoyed food from Icebergs and Santa Vittoria drinks while viewing the minimalist, androgynous designs on an unseasonably warm 28°C day. The unusual venue attracted attention from beachgoers and passersby who stopped to watch the show.

# Summary of the Passage

Amir Khan, a 28-year-old boxer from Bolton, spent Friday at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom safari park in Northern California with his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa. During their family outing, Khan interacted with various animals, including feeding a rare white tiger and posing with giraffes and sea lions. The passage also mentions Khan's professional boxing career, noting that he recently announced his next fight will be against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, despite speculation and pressure for him to face British rival Kell Brook.

# Summary of the Passage

The passage describes a controversy over the inclusion of Palestinian teenager Mohammed Abu Khdeir's name on an Israeli memorial wall at Mount Herzl that commemorates fallen soldiers and terrorism victims. Abu Khdeir, who was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, had his name added to the memorial as Israel prepared for its Memorial Day. His father objected, stating he didn't give permission and refused to have his son "listed between soldiers of the occupation." Almagor, an organization representing Israeli terror victims, also opposed the inclusion, describing Abu Khdeir's death as a "rogue attack" rather than terrorism. Following complaints, the National Insurance Institute of Israel decided to remove Abu Khdeir's name from the memorial wall, and had already removed it from their website.

# Summary of the Passage

The passage describes a humorous interaction between a young boy and a cat, captured on video by YouTube user Lionel Hutz in California. The boy repeatedly attempts to use the cat's belly as a pillow, chasing the feline around the garden. Each time the boy lies down on the cat, the animal gets up and moves to a different location, with the persistent child following and trying again. After several attempts, the cat eventually retreats indoors to escape being used as a pillow. A follow-up video shows the two reconciled, with the boy gently feeding treats to the cat.

# Summary of Police Corruption Trial Passage

A police corruption trial in Philadelphia involves testimony from former drug dealers against six police officers accused of racketeering. One witness, Robert Kushner, lost his varsity coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his history of selling marijuana. Kushner testified that undercover officers on trial had stolen $81,000 and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. School officials were unaware of his criminal history despite a background check when he was hired in 2010. Kushner's legal troubles include a 2007 arrest with expunged charges, a 2011 arrest resulting in four years probation, and a 2008 DUI guilty plea. Defense lawyers claim the government's case relies on testimony from "19 lying drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop."

# Summary of the Passage

An explosion at a controversial paraxylene (PX) chemical plant in Zhangzhou city, Fujian province, China, caused a large fire and injured six people. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility following an oil leak, with five people injured by broken glass. Over 600 firefighters brought the fire under control. This was the second explosion at the plant since July 2013. The plant, which produces PX (a reportedly carcinogenic chemical used in polyester production), has been controversial in China, with its construction sparking protests in several cities. It was originally planned for Xiamen but was relocated to a more remote location in 2007 due to pollution concerns and public opposition.

# Summary of the Passage

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa teenager, insists on keeping his socks low just above his shinpads despite referees telling him to pull them up. This is a lifelong superstition he refuses to change. Grealish wears children's-sized shinpads, which makes it appear he isn't wearing any protection. He made his first Premier League start in a 3-3 draw against QPR and expressed mixed feelings about the debut, being pleased to start but disappointed with the game's outcome. Grealish appreciated his manager's faith in him and hopes to secure more starts before the season ends.

# Summary of Passage

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has been diagnosed with "global and irreversible brain damage" according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston. Despite no longer being in a medically induced coma, she remains unresponsive. This assessment contradicts Bobby Brown's recent public statement that his daughter was "awake" and "watching" him. A family attorney clarified that while her condition has improved enough to leave the ICU and begin rehabilitation, the quality of her life remains uncertain. According to a source, she does not respond to visitors or voices, her eyes don't track movement, and she has a tracheostomy. The family is facing the possibility that she may remain in this condition long-term.

# Summary of the Passage

Russia is close to reaching the Fed Cup final with a 2-0 lead over Germany. Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point before defeating Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6(4), 6-3, while Svetlana Kuznetsova beat Julia Goerges in straight sets in the opening match. Despite Pavlyuchenkova's 13 double faults, Lisicki's 63 unforced errors proved decisive. Russia now needs just one win from Sunday's three remaining matches to advance to the final and potentially claim their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

# Concise Summary of Passage

New South Wales residents are being warned to prepare for more potential flooding and damage as meteorologists predict another east coast low weather system could hit the region later this week, bringing heavy rain from Thursday through Saturday. The State Emergency Service (SES) is particularly concerned about the Hunter region, which was severely impacted by the previous storm. With over 4,000 jobs still pending from the 24,196 requests received during last week's three-day storm, the SES fears that additional rain on already saturated ground could raise flood levels again and strong winds could topple weakened trees. Unlike the previous storm, this weather system is expected to impact the far northern parts of the state more heavily and may move through more quickly, lasting about two days rather than three. The SES is working to complete as many outstanding jobs as possible before the new system arrives and is urging residents to prepare their homes and families to prevent further damage.

# Summary of the Passage

After posting photos of bruises on her Instagram account, Italian media claimed she had tried to take her own life and was found by her mother in her Milan apartment. However, Moric clarified that she was hospitalized after falling and hitting her head due to low blood pressure while her boyfriend was in Naples. The passage describes a suicide bombing that occurred in eastern Afghanistan on Thursday. The bomber detonated explosives near protesters in the city of Khost, killing 17 people and wounding 64 others, including an Afghan lawmaker. The protesters, led by Humayoon Humayoon (a member of parliament for Khost province), were on their way to join a larger rally against the provincial governor when the attack happened around 10 a.m. local time. Taliban spokesman Zabiullah Mujahid denied his group's involvement, and no other organization has claimed responsibility for the attack.

The passage discusses Dani Alves' impending departure from Barcelona after rejecting the club's final contract offer. After seven successful years with Barcelona, during which he won four Spanish titles and two Champions League trophies, the 31-year-old Brazilian right-back has been unable to reach an agreement on a new deal. His agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, confirmed at a press conference that Alves rejected Barcelona's offer of a three-year extension that was contingent on him playing in 60% of the club's matches. She declared that negotiations were over, expressing frustration that Barcelona waited until April to consider renewing his contract.

The passage discusses Pablo Osvaldo's desire for Italian football legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at Boca Juniors in Argentina. The passage notes that Pirlo is considered one of the world's best midfielders, while Totti is a Roma legend who Osvaldo believes would be equally appreciated in Argentina.

The passage describes 18-year-old amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson's spectacular fall from his horse Merrion Square during a race at Wincanton. Despite performing a double somersault fall that became an internet sensation with hundreds of thousands of views online, Ferguson escaped with only a cut on his nose. The day after the incident, he was back to his normal duties at Paul Nicholls's yard, mucking out stables and riding horses. Ferguson described the fall as "a blur" that he only understood after watching the replay with other jockeys who "looked away in horror." He maintained his sense of humor about the incident, joking about possibly pursuing gymnastics after his racing career, and noted he received some good-natured teasing from colleagues while gaining Twitter followers from the viral video.

The passage describes how England rugby player James Haskell posted a photo of himself dressed as Iron Man on Instagram, coinciding with the release of "Avengers: Age of Ultron." The post included the caption about releasing his "inner Iron Man." The passage details Haskell's career trajectory, noting that he is the London Wasps captain who first joined the club in 2002, left in 2009 to play internationally with teams in France, Japan, and New Zealand, before returning to Wasps in 2012. Since his return, he has made over 100 appearances for the club and earned 57 caps for England's national team.

# Summary of the Passage

The University of Michigan reversed its decision to cancel a screening of "American Sniper" after initially pulling the film due to a petition signed by over 200 students who objected to its portrayal of the Iraq War and Middle Eastern people. The university acknowledged that canceling the film was inconsistent with their values of freedom of expression and students' right to choose. The passage describes an incident where two French tourists, aged 18 and 24, allegedly attempted to harm a quokka on Rottnest Island off Perth, Western Australia on April 3. They used an aerosol spray ignited with a lighter to create a flame that made contact with the animal. The quokka survived but was singed by the flame. Detectives investigated the incident, seized video evidence, and evicted the tourists from the island. Both men, who were living in Cockburn Central, have been charged with animal cruelty and are scheduled to appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. The passage also notes that quokkas are cat-sized animals found on small islands off the West Australian coast, particularly Rottnest Island and Bald Island near Albany.

The passage describes how 102-year-old Alice Barker, a former dancer who performed in New York nightspots like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar during the 1930s and 1940s, recently viewed footage of herself dancing for the first time. Barker had been part of chorus lines that performed alongside notable entertainers such as Bill "Bojangles" Robinson and Frank Sinatra. Although motion pictures of her performances existed, she had never seen them, and all her photographs and memorabilia had been lost over time. Mark Cantor from Jazz-on-Film.com and volunteers created a video of "soundies" (early music videos) featuring Barker and showed them to her at her nursing home, which she described as "fabulous."

# Summary of Car Washing Habits in Britain

The passage describes the decline of car washing as a personal activity in Britain. According to a survey by vehicle leasing firm OSV of 1,100 adults:

- One-third of men have never washed their own car, with only 12% doing it regularly
- Three-quarters of women never wash their own car
- Only 5% of people have asked their children to wash cars for pocket money
- Factors contributing to this decline include:
  * Sunday shopping and live football on TV
  * Rise of hand car washes
  * Larger vehicles like 4x4s being too difficult to clean

The survey found regional differences, with cars most likely to be washed weekly in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield, and least likely in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh. Car washing by owners is most common during holidays, with 15 million cars cleaned during Easter break, though 25% admitted doing it just to escape the house.

The passage discusses Martin Skrtel's praise for Steven Gerrard as the Liverpool captain approaches the end of his time with the club before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel considers Gerrard "one of the best players in the world" and acknowledges how Gerrard helped him settle at Liverpool after his 2008 arrival from Zenit St. Petersburg. While Skrtel believes Liverpool "will never be the same" without Gerrard, he expresses confidence that the club has potential replacements who can step up with proper support. The passage mentions that both players could return to Liverpool's lineup for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa after serving three-match bans, with Gerrard hoping to reach the final which falls on his birthday, May 30.

# Summary of the Passage

At age 75, Jack Nicklaus hit a hole-in-one during the par-3 contest at Augusta National, on the 130-yard fourth hole. He was playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. Nicklaus mentioned in an interview earlier that day that he wanted to "win the par-3 and make a hole in one." This was Nicklaus's first ace at Augusta. The day saw a total of five holes-in-one, tying the record from 2002. Colombian golfer Camilo Villegas also made two aces but lost the title to Kevin Streelman in a playoff. Nicklaus, known as "the Golden Bear," won his first Masters in 1963 and his sixth in 1986, and is one of five golfers to complete the career grand slam.

# Summary of the Passage

The passage describes an incident where Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott "skolled" (quickly drank) a beer at an Australian rules football function, drawing criticism from anti-drinking campaigners. Julie Robert, a cultural studies professor at the University of Technology Sydney, called Abbott's behavior "problematic," arguing that it glorifies binge drinking and associates masculinity with alcohol consumption. The incident occurred when Abbott downed a schooner of beer in about six seconds while being cheered on by players. 

Critics contend that as Prime Minister, Abbott should be advocating against binge drinking rather than reinforcing the stereotype that drinking heavily makes one a "true blue Aussie bloke." Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott, highlighting his fitness routine. The passage notes that while former Prime Minister Bob Hawke also demonstrated similar drinking behavior, attitudes toward heavy drinking have shifted in recent years, with increased concern about binge drinking.

# Summary of HIV Outbreak in Scott County, Indiana

Indiana is experiencing a significant increase in HIV cases in Scott County, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary positive cases as of the report, up from 106 the previous week. The outbreak is primarily occurring among intravenous drug users who use the painkiller Opana.

Governor Mike Pence approved a temporary 30-day needle exchange program on March 26, despite his general opposition to such programs. As of the report, 5,322 clean syringes had been provided to 86 participants, with about 1,400 used syringes returned. Officials note participation has increased as trust builds through mobile outreach efforts.

The governor is reviewing whether to extend the program beyond April 25. Meanwhile, legislation that would allow needle exchanges in 23 Indiana counties with high hepatitis C rates (an indicator of potential HIV outbreaks) is being considered, though its fate remains uncertain. Some lawmakers view needle exchanges as harm-reduction policy rather than anti-drug policy.

Challenges include concerns that needle exchanges might promote drug use, sustainability issues, and funding limitations due to the federal ban on public funding for such programs since 1989.

# Summary of the Arsenal Fan Test Passage

An Arsenal fan created a formal exam for his girlfriend Saskia to test her knowledge of the football club. The test included multiple-choice questions, tables to complete, and written responses about Arsenal FC. Saskia scored an impressive 43.5 out of 50 (87%), earning an "A" grade. Her boyfriend jokingly commented that he "will not be dumping" her because of her good performance.

The test covered various aspects of Arsenal knowledge including player positions, match results, and team history. Saskia struggled with some player positions but earned extra points for creative answers, particularly her critique of rival player Eden Hazard. She shared the exam on Twitter (@saskiaisabxlla), where it generated mixed reactions - some male fans praised her boyfriend as a "legend" and called Saskia "proper girlfriend material," while others criticized the boyfriend for taking his fandom too far, with one calling him a "biff-head."

The post inspired some men to consider testing their own girlfriends' football knowledge, while others questioned the extreme nature of the test.

# Summary of the Passage

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former member of the Medellin cartel, worked as an undercover informant for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for promised US citizenship. After fleeing Colombia in the 1980s fearing for his life, Toro provided valuable information that helped prosecute major figures including Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Despite not being paid for his work, Toro conducted undercover operations worldwide, becoming one of the DEA's most important assets. Now retired due to declining health, Toro faces deportation as his temporary visa expired on January 1, and the DEA has refused to help him obtain citizenship after he went public with his situation. Toro fears being killed if returned to Colombia, stating "the United States government has sentenced me to death." Former DEA handler Mike McManus personally gave Toro $5,000 for an operation and believes Toro deserves to stay in the US after his service.

# Summary of the Passage

A newborn baby named Star Reader was diagnosed with biliary atresia shortly after birth when her parents noticed her skin had a yellowy tinge. After an unsuccessful operation to unblock her bile ducts, doctors determined she needed a liver transplant to survive. Neither parent was a suitable match for donation, but Star's maternal aunt, Shanell Reader (the twin sister of Star's mother Jade), volunteered and was found to be an ideal candidate. The transplant operation took place in November, and after six weeks in hospital, Star returned home and has made a good recovery. She will require ongoing blood tests and will be on anti-rejection medication for life, but now has the chance to live normally thanks to her aunt's selfless donation.

# Summary of the Passage

Robert Dellinger, a 54-year-old former Fortune 500 executive, claimed during his sentencing that he was not suicidal when he caused a fatal highway crash in December 2013. The crash killed Amanda Murphy, who was eight months pregnant, and her fiancé Jason Timmons when Dellinger's pickup truck crossed a median at over 100mph and hit their SUV. Despite initially telling investigators he was trying to kill himself, Dellinger stated in court that he has "never been suicidal." # Summary of the Passage

Lacey Spears was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for killing her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, by poisoning him with salt through his feeding tube. The boy's father, Chris Hill, expressed anger on Facebook following the sentencing, stating he hoped she would be placed in general population where "she won't make it" and that she "needs to be beat to death in prison." Hill also noted Spears showed no emotion during sentencing. The judge acknowledged Spears suffers from mental illness but called her crime "unfathomable in its cruelty." Prosecutors, who sought the maximum 25-year sentence, argued Spears made her son ill due to a "bizarre need for attention" and documented his suffering on social media. Her defense attorney requested a minimum sentence and plans to appeal, claiming hospital negligence. Throughout his short life, Garnett endured numerous unnecessary hospitalizations and medical procedures at his mother's hands.

# Concise Summary of the Passage

The passage discusses the delayed arrival of an improved influenza vaccine in Australia, which is coming a month later than expected. The new vaccine has been modified to include protection against two additional strains: influenza A strain H3N2 and influenza B strain B/Phuket. These strains caused increased deaths in Europe and the United States during the northern winter because the previous vaccine was not effective against them.

High-risk groups, including the very young, elderly, and most indigenous Australians, will have access to free government-funded flu shots starting April 20. Dr. Alan Hampson, chair of the Influenza Specialist Group, emphasizes that everyone should get vaccinated, not just high-risk individuals. He notes that the modified vaccine should be a good match for globally circulating strains and recommends people book their flu shots now despite the delay in availability.

# Summary of Abraham Lincoln's Tomb Situation

The passage discusses challenges facing Abraham Lincoln's tomb in Springfield, Illinois during the 150th anniversary of his assassination. Key points include:

1. The tomb faces criticism from National Geographic magazine, which described it as having "all the historical character of an office lobby" and called it "a disappointment."

2. Budget concerns threaten the site's management, with Illinois Governor Bruce Rauner proposing to eliminate the state historic preservation agency that oversees the tomb.

3. Previous budget cuts of $1.1 million have already reduced the tomb's operating hours and staff.

4. Supporters defend the tomb, noting that over $2.5 million in recent renovations have left it in "excellent physical condition," including interior renovations costing approximately $730,000.

5. The tomb, designed by Vermont sculptor Larkin Mead and dedicated by President Grant in 1874, has been reconstructed twice (1899 and 1930) and features marble and bronze construction with Lincoln's burial chamber bearing the inscription "Now he belongs to the ages."

# Summary of the Passage

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani free speech advocate and owner of a café called "The Second Floor" (T2F) in Karachi, was murdered by two gunmen after hosting a controversial discussion about disappearances in Baluchistan province. Mahmud was shot five times at point-blank range; her mother was also shot but survived. Known for creating a space where people could freely discuss technology, human rights, and progressive values, Mahmud had become a figurehead for humanism and tolerance in Pakistan. The discussion she hosted just before her death had been previously canceled at a university due to authorities' intervention. Despite receiving death threats in the past, Mahmud continued to provide a platform for open dialogue on sensitive topics. Her death prompted an outpouring of grief from those who valued her courage and commitment to free expression in a country where speaking freely can be dangerous.

# Summary of Passage on West Pakistan Refugees in Kashmir

The passage describes the plight of West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) in Indian Kashmir, focusing on 82-year-old Mangu Ram who fled during the 1947 Partition. Despite living in India for nearly 70 years, these Hindu refugees are denied full citizenship rights in Kashmir, India's only Muslim-majority state. They cannot own property, vote in state elections, attend state-run colleges, or work for the state government.

Approximately 100,000 WPRs, mostly living in the Jammu region, have been trapped in poverty for three generations due to a pre-independence law that only grants citizenship to those born in the undivided kingdom of Kashmir. The reluctance to grant them full rights stems from concerns about altering the demographic balance in the Muslim-majority state.

However, there is new hope following the recent election of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) to a coalition government in Kashmir. The BJP is expected to champion the refugees' cause, though activist Labha Ram Gandhi warns that if their hopes are dashed again, the community may take more drastic action.

# Summary of the Passage

Open Garden has developed Greenstone, an egg-shaped device designed to strengthen off-the-grid wireless mesh networks used by their FireChat app. FireChat, downloaded over five million times, allows users to communicate without internet or mobile signals by creating mesh networks where phones act as nodes to relay messages. The app utilizes Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) in iOS 7 and similar Bluetooth functionality on Android.

While FireChat's mesh networks typically have a range limitation of about 200 feet, Greenstone acts as a beacon or booster to extend this range. The device can store up to 1,000 recent messages with a one-year battery life, holding messages until a FireChat user comes within its approximately 20-foot range.

This technology is particularly useful in situations with limited connectivity such as planes, underground locations, music festivals, protests, or during emergencies. Open Garden is currently working with manufacturers to bring Greenstone to market.

# Summary of the Passage

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer from New Jersey, is working to destigmatize the word "fat" by embracing it as a neutral descriptor of her body rather than an insult. During her TED talk, she explained that "fat" should be treated like other descriptive terms such as "short" or "wife" - simply factual rather than negative. 

Bustle highlighted concerning statistics: workplace size discrimination has increased 66% over the past 30 years, and the top wish for girls aged 11-17 is to be thinner. However, she also noted that studies show increased exposure to body diversity leads to greater acceptance of different body types.

At 240 pounds, Bustle found empowerment through burlesque performance, which she began in 2012. Though initially nervous about her appearance, performing helped her build confidence. She encourages others to find their own "courage reference" - a brave moment to recall during times of insecurity.

Her TED talk, posted to YouTube three weeks prior, has garnered nearly 38,000 views with predominantly positive feedback, including messages from people who reconsidered their body perceptions after watching.

# Summary of Rick Baker's Prop and Puppet Auction

A significant collection of props and puppets created by legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker will be auctioned on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on propstore.com. The collection from Baker's Cinovation Studio includes 417 original items from over 50 productions spanning his 30-year career, with an estimated total value of $746,100.

Notable items include:

# Summary of the Passage

Seven-year-old British boy Carwyn Scott-Howell died in a tragic skiing accident in the French Alps. While skiing with his family in Flaine, he became separated from his mother when she stopped to help his sister who had lost a ski. Carwyn, described as a "very competent skier," apparently left the piste and entered woodland, likely trying to reach the resort he could see through the trees. Police followed his footprints in the snow, which led to where he had fallen over a 164-foot drop. His family described him as "daring, outgoing and determined" with a smile that "lit up any room," stating his death has left "a vast void in their hearts." Carwyn, from Talybont-on-Usk in Wales, was known in his community for his lively personality and his family's award-winning farm shop.

# Summary of the Passage

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia at age 13 after feeling pressured to achieve a "size zero" figure. Her condition became so severe that she was surviving on approximately 100 calories a day, often just a piece of fruit, while hiding food and lying to her mother about eating. After her body began shutting down, she collapsed and was hospitalized on a heart monitor for a week. Following her hospitalization, Laura received support from eating disorder organizations and began her recovery. Initially motivated by bullying about her weight and media pressure to be thin, Laura has now regained her health and confidence, even reaching the semi-finals of Miss Teen GB, a competition that aims to promote positive experiences for young girls away from size zero stereotypes.

# Concise Summary of the Passage

During the event, Sterling faced pressure from fans to stay at the club, with one fan's comment "make sure we see you in that next season" receiving applause. This comes after Sterling recently rejected a £100,000-a-week contract and expressed being flattered by interest from Arsenal.

The players also discussed the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley, with Sterling noting it was special to play in his hometown and Sturridge emphasizing the importance of winning the FA Cup as a platform for future success.

The new kit features all-white branding, a new collar style, and includes the memorial flame and number 96 in tribute to the Hillsborough disaster victims.

# High-Definition Dark Matter Map Summary

Researchers from the University of Manchester, led by Dr. Sarah Bridle, have produced the largest single high-definition map of dark matter, covering 0.4 percent of the night sky (approximately 150 times the area of the full moon). This map is the first in a series that will eventually create a 3D view of dark matter across one-eighth of the night sky.

The map was created using data from the Dark Energy Camera, a 570-megapixel device mounted on the Victor M. Blanco telescope in Chile as part of the five-year Dark Energy Survey (DES). Since dark matter cannot be directly observed, scientists studied its gravitational effects on galaxies through a technique called gravitational lensing.

The map reveals large filaments of dark matter where galaxies and galaxy clusters tend to form, supporting current cosmological theories that galaxies form in areas with higher concentrations of dark matter. The research team analyzed 130 million separate telescope images using supercomputers to measure galaxy shapes with extreme precision.

The ultimate goal of the DES is to map 12.5 percent of the entire sky by 2018, creating a comprehensive 3D map of both dark matter and dark energy. This will help scientists better understand the nature of dark energy, which is believed to be causing the universe's expansion to accelerate.

# Summary of the Passage

Manchester United have made an official approach for PSV Eindhoven's 21-year-old star Memphis Depay, as confirmed by the Dutch club. United manager Louis van Gaal, who previously worked with Depay during Holland's 2014 World Cup campaign where they finished third, is keen to make him one of his first summer signings. PSV's technical director Marcel Brands revealed that Manchester United, Paris Saint-Germain, and another major European club have shown interest, with the asking price now higher than Tottenham's rejected £15 million bid last summer.

Depay is having an exceptional season, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games for PSV, who recently won their first Eredivisie title in seven years. The young winger, known for his pace, dribbling ability, and powerful right foot, has been compared favorably to Arjen Robben and even a young Cristiano Ronaldo. Depay began his career at VV Moordrecht before joining PSV at age 12, and has already made over 100 appearances for the club. He also impressed at the 2014 World Cup under Van Gaal, scoring against Australia and Chile.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate, stated that while he believes people are born with their sexual preferences, he does not consider same-sex marriage a constitutional right. Pablo Mandado (27, Spanish) and Ilze Zebolde (31, Latvian) are a couple cycling around the world with no fixed plans or agenda. After quitting their restaurant jobs in Manchester, they've been traveling for nearly a year, covering almost 7,000 miles across 16 countries. They live extremely frugally, spending less than €3 each per day (€0.10 per kilometer), with food as their main expense at €2.74 daily. # Summary of the Passage

A Texas couple who married in 2012 is suing Premiere Photos and its owner James Evans for allegedly printing racial slurs ("poor n***** party") on photo booth snapshots at their wedding. The bride's sister discovered the offensive captions but waited to inform the couple to avoid ruining the wedding day. When the groom eventually contacted Evans about the incident, Evans reportedly responded with "sue me" and offered no apology. The couple, represented by attorney Cathy Hale, filed a lawsuit under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, claiming negligence and breach of contract. Evans has denied all allegations, stating there's no evidence linking his company to the offensive captions among the 103 guests at the event. The case was scheduled for mediation, with a trial set for July if no agreement was reached. According to their attorney, the couple primarily wants an apology rather than financial compensation.

# Concise Summary of the Passage

Mike Brown, England's full-back, is taking a cautious approach to recovery following his recent concussion issues. After experiencing headaches following a France game, Brown withdrew from Harlequins' match against Saracens at Wembley. He remains uncertain about his return timeline, emphasizing the importance of following proper recovery protocols to avoid extended absences like those experienced by George North, Johnny Sexton, and Geoff Parling.

Brown had previously been knocked unconscious during England's victory over Italy in February and later withdrew from the Ireland match. He credits increased awareness about concussion symptoms, gained through World Rugby online modules, for helping him make responsible decisions about his health. Brown advocates for player safety, stating that if he could pull out of a crucial Six Nations match, other players should also prioritize their health when experiencing concussion symptoms.

# Summary of the Passage

Research indicates that the frequency of sexual activity among British couples has declined since the emergence of the internet. According to Professor David Spiegelhalter of Cambridge University, heterosexual couples now have sex approximately three times per month, compared to four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. The professor suggests smartphone use and constant connectivity may be responsible for this decline, as the boundaries between public and private lives have eroded. People checking emails constantly and having busier, more connected lives has "squeezed out" intimate time with partners. Catherine Mercer, a researcher cited in the article, notes that sex has fallen down people's list of priorities due to competing demands on time, with evening work emails making it difficult to focus on one's partner at bedtime.

# Summary of Tibetan Mastiffs in China

Tibetan mastiffs, large dogs weighing up to 80 kg that were traditionally used in Tibet for herding, have experienced a dramatic decline in popularity in China. Just a year ago, they commanded prices up to £1.2 million each, with one puppy selling for that record amount 13 months ago.

Now, these once-prized dogs are being sent to slaughterhouses, where their meat is used in cheap hotpots and their skin for leather belts. This decline is attributed to several factors:

1. The Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown has stopped the practice of giving mastiffs as gifts to influence officials
2. Bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several major Chinese cities
3. Cross-breeding that deteriorated the breed's appearance and temperament
4. Increasing urbanization making people realize these dogs aren't suited to city living

Animal welfare workers recently rescued 20 mastiffs being transported to a slaughterhouse in cramped cages, with a third already dead and others suffering from broken bones. Hundreds more are reportedly meeting similar fates across China, with some being stolen from streets by gangs or discarded by breeders as "imperfect" specimens.

# Summary of the Passage

According to a survey of 600 women in Paris, every female respondent reported experiencing some form of sexual harassment on public transportation. Half of these women were first harassed before age 18. The harassment ranges from insults and intimidating behavior to sexual attacks. This widespread issue causes 60% of women to fear being attacked on public transport (compared to 30% of men) and forces many women to alter their daily routines, routes, and clothing to avoid confrontation. The High Council for Gender Equality, which compiled the report for the French women's rights ministry, has called for a campaign to address this sexist and threatening behavior, emphasizing that women's freedom to move safely in public spaces is a fundamental right that is currently being compromised.

# Summary of the Passage

Direct Line is running a competition called #everydayfix where prototype products designed to solve common everyday problems are being voted on by the public. The winning design will be funded through Kickstarter and developed into an actual product. The three shortlisted prototypes are:

1. "Snooze" - an alarm clock that connects to your phone and silences notifications to help with sleep problems (the top concern in a survey of 2,000 people)

2. "Forget Me Lock" - a device that attaches to keys and changes color (green for unlocked, red for locked) to reassure people about whether they locked their door

3. "Nipper" - claimed to be the world's smallest mobile phone charger, using household batteries as an energy source

Other designs that didn't make the final shortlist included a parking space alert system, a message relay app for when phones die, and a navigation helmet for cyclists. The public can vote for their favorite by retweeting with the hashtag #everydayfix by April 46, with the most popular design moving forward to development.

Valecce has since had the tattoos removed but continues to suffer psychological trauma from the attack.
